questions.question_text: A rule-based data loss prevention (DLP) tool has recently been implemented to reduce the risk of sensitive data leakage. Which of the following is MOST likely to change as a result of this implementation?

discussion.content: Risk impact when sensitive data is leaked will remain the same. The DLP will reduce the risk likelihood (Answer C). Any type of data that has a rule in the DLP will be protected.

comments.content: Not quite understand how the risk impact is same if the sensitive data is leaked. There could be huge impact if the sensitive data is leaked, say your company’s secret formula or your customers’ personal data.

because the impact if the sensitive data is leaked is the same, regardless of the reason (control bypass, control failure, ...). what the DLP is doing is just help prevent the leakage (probability/likelihood), but in the case the document gets leaked then, the impact is the same. unlike for example redacting a sensitive document. this control will reduce its sensitivity, and thus it's impact if it ever gets released.

discussion.content:
Reducing risk impact is for corrective controls, ie- backup. DLP is considered as preventive control, and preventive controls reduces probability. 

Anyhow, I'm open for discussions.

Selected Answer: B
I agree it is C from using logic, but from the diagram in the ISACA review manual 7th edition on page 152 it is clear that preventive reduces impact, deterrent reduces likelihood.

comments.content: The next question, 724, raises the same dilemma. Really seems like C is the answer, both from common sense / real world interactions AND Google searches that include both impact and likelihood reduction for preventive controls. Bless ISACA...

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Well, correction, reason:
The implementation of a rule-based data loss prevention (DLP) tool is likely to reduce the risk likelihood of sensitive data leakage.

The purpose of the DLP tool is to prevent the unauthorized transmission of sensitive data outside the organization's network by applying rules to identify and block sensitive data from leaving the network. By preventing the unauthorized transmission of sensitive data, the tool can significantly reduce the likelihood of data leakage incidents occurring.

Selected Answer: B
Curious answers.
A DLP (Data loss 'prevention') system is a 'preventive' control (7th CRISC manual 'control types, standards and frameworks' section), and these types of controls by their nature reduce impact, not probability.

For more information, controls capable of reducing probability are 'deterrents' or 'compensatory'.
Preventative Controls first reduce the likelihood , then impact.

Selected Answer: B
B. Inherent risk

When an organization completes a project to implement encryption on all databases hosting customer data, it is effectively reducing the inherent risk associated with the exposure of customer data. Inherent risk refers to the level of risk that exists before any controls or mitigation measures are applied. By implementing encryption, the organization is reducing the inherent risk of unauthorized access or data breaches.

It is D. You only change inherent risk when you add or change activities / processes. And I am still stuck on the 723 before this one where the chart on pg 152 of the 7th review manual indicates that preventive controls reduce impact. Still picking D, and should probably change my answer on 723.

Question with a little trick. A preventive control (such as encryption) reduces the impact, not the probability. I would choose the inherent risk, even knowing that this is not the best option (it exists regardless of the application of controls).

Answer B appears best. Encryption project is completed so subsequent analysis should consider encryption as an existing control when assessing inherent risk. Furthermore, encryption is a preventive control and does not reduce the likelihood, hence D is not an option.
I pick D. Inherent risk is the total risk without any control. encryption is lower the risk of data explore to public. So it is risk likelihood.

questions.question_text: An organization has completed a project to implement encryption on all databases that host customer data. Which of the following elements of the risk register should be updated to reflect this change?
A business unit is updating a risk register with assessment results for a key project. Which of the following is MOST important to capture in the register?

choices.C: An assigned risk manager to provide oversight
choices.B: The team that performed the risk assessment
choices.A: Action plans to address risk scenarios requiring treatment
choices.D: The methodology used to perform the risk assessment

discussion.content: I thought the action plan is the most important to capture in a risk register to follow up on risk remediation. Since when did we start capturing risk methodologies in risk registers?

Selected Answer: A
A. Action plans to address risk scenarios requiring treatment

When updating a risk register with assessment results for a key project, the most important information to capture is the action plans to address risk scenarios that require treatment. This information is crucial because it outlines the specific steps and measures that the organization will take to mitigate or manage the identified risks. It helps ensure that risks are actively addressed and that the project can proceed with risk mitigation strategies in place.

While the other options (B, C, and D) are also relevant and important for maintaining a comprehensive risk register, action plans for risk treatment are the primary focus because they directly address how the organization intends to manage and reduce the impact of identified risks.

Selected Answer: A
A it is.

Selected Answer: A

Selected Answer: A
Capturing the action plans to address risk scenarios requiring treatment in the risk register is the most important as it highlights the measures that the organization plans to take in response to the identified risks.
 The risk register should provide a clear picture of the organization's approach to managing risk and the steps being taken to mitigate risk scenarios. 
The action plans should outline the responsible parties, timelines, and resources required to effectively address the risks, helping to ensure that the risk response is aligned with the organization's goals and objectives. 
The other elements, such as the team that performed the risk assessment, the assigned risk manager, and the methodology used, may provide important information, but the action plans are the primary objective as they demonstrate the organization's commitment to risk management and its preparedness to address risk scenarios.

Senior management has asked a risk practitioner to develop technical risk scenarios related to a recently developed enterprise resource planning (ERP) system.
These scenarios will be owned by the system manager. Which of the following would be the BEST method to use when developing the scenarios?

discussion.content: A. Bottom-up approach would be better for technical scenarios as the employees will provide better technical knowledge.

Selected Answer: A
A. Bottom-up approach

When developing technical risk scenarios, especially for a specific system such as an ERP, a bottom-up approach is typically more effective. This approach begins at the technical or operational level and moves upward. It involves a detailed examination of the system components, interactions, vulnerabilities, and threats specific to that system. The bottom-up approach ensures that the unique technical intricacies and risks of the system are taken into consideration.

In contrast, a top-down approach begins at the strategic or high-level perspective and moves downward. It's more focused on broader organizational goals and strategies.

A cause-and-effect diagram, while useful for understanding the relationship between different factors, isn't the primary tool for scenario development.

The Delphi technique is a forecasting method based on the results of multiple rounds of questionnaires sent to a panel of experts. It's not typically the primary method for technical risk scenario development for a specific system.

Selected Answer: A
Believe it would be A. The question talks about the ERP system and the system owner, and bottom up aligns best with risk to systems.
